entry.value: This page features controls that feature validation in Rapid.

Rapid comes with the ability to validate controls on the page in a variety of different ways. Validating controls is a great way of preventing further actions on your page and informing users on what to do in the event validation fails. Below are a few examples of some simple validation to include in your Rapid applications.

Below we have a couple of input boxes linked to the 'Validate' button. Both input boxes have different validation messages attached to them, and we will go over some of the different validation types in the next page. For this validation type it will activate whenever you change the contents of the input boxes.

Input boxes are not the only controls in Rapid that can be validated. Any control that has a validation header can have validation applied to it, and any control can be used to check validation, not just our 'Validate' button above. In our next example we will be validating the date control and the radio button controls.

validation.message: Please enter your date of birth

entry.value: We've seen quite a few different controls with validation now, but there is more to cover! When in the Rapid Designer and control that has a validation header can be validated against. All controls can have a validation action applied to them, however the general use of this is to attach it to a button, like we have used throughout this page. Below are the remaining controls with validation.

validation.message: Please rate how today's weather is

entry.value: [{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P8_C18_","text":"For this validation we are going to use the change event. This even will activate every time a change has occurred that is different from what it was before. For example, in our input box if we had a name in there and removed it then validation would activate and tell us that we have not passed. Validation can also be triggered by other means, such as pressing a button with a validation check. For more information on validation types we have an entire video dedicated to this. Click on this hint icon to go to that video.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P8_C84_","text":"Validation on Rapid can be customised using CSS by overwriting what is currently set for validation styles. Some validation will appear slightly differently on the various Rapid themes available, for example the radio buttons in the Rapid theme are larger than normal so validation has been altered to suit the specific look and feel of the theme. This also applies to the other themes available in Rapid. This is the beauty of Rapid. Everything can be customised freely and extensively, or not at all based on how you think it looks.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P8_C130_","text":"In Rapid not everything has a pre-set validation styling method. For example, our checkbox and score controls do not change when we add validation onto them, but they can still be validated against and a message can be provided to guide users on what steps to take next. The checkbox control has a more specialised way of validation, as shown in the example.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P8_C18_","text":"For this validation we are going to use the change event. This even will activate every time a change has occurred that is different from what it was before. For example, in our input box if we had a name in there and removed it then validation would activate and tell us that we have not passed. Validation can also be triggered by other means, such as pressing a button with a validation check. For more information on validation types we have an entire video dedicated to this. Click on this hint icon to go to that video.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P8_C84_","text":"Validation on Rapid can be customised using CSS by overwriting what is currently set for validation styles. Some validation will appear slightly differently on the various Rapid themes available, for example the radio buttons in the Rapid theme are larger than normal so validation has been altered to suit the specific look and feel of the theme. This also applies to the other themes available in Rapid. This is the beauty of Rapid. Everything can be customised freely and extensively, or not at all based on how you think it looks.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P8_C130_","text":"In Rapid not everything has a pre-set validation styling method. For example, our checkbox and score controls do not change when we add validation onto them, but they can still be validated against and a message can be provided to guide users on what steps to take next. The checkbox control has a more specialised way of validation, as shown in the example.","type":"hover"}]}

page.htmlBody:
This page features controls that feature validation in Rapid.

Rapid comes with the ability to validate controls on the page in a variety of different ways. Validating controls is a great way of preventing further actions on your page and informing users on what to do in the event validation fails. Below are a few examples of some simple validation to include in your Rapid applications.
Below we have a couple of input boxes linked to the 'Validate' button. Both input boxes have different validation messages attached to them, and we will go over some of the different validation types in the next page. For this validation type it will activate whenever you change the contents of the input boxes.
First name
Last name
Input boxes are not the only controls in Rapid that can be validated. Any control that has a validation header can have validation applied to it, and any control can be used to check validation, not just our 'Validate' button above. In our next example we will be validating the date control and the radio button controls.
Birthday
Gender
We've seen quite a few different controls with validation now, but there is more to cover! When in the Rapid Designer and control that has a validation header can be validated against. All controls can have a validation action applied to them, however the general use of this is to attach it to a button, like we have used throughout this page. Below are the remaining controls with validation.
Country
Not a robot
Today's weatherABCD
page.name: 10_validation

rolesHtml.html:
This page features controls that feature validation in Rapid.

Rapid comes with the ability to validate controls on the page in a variety of different ways. Validating controls is a great way of preventing further actions on your page and informing users on what to do in the event validation fails. Below are a few examples of some simple validation to include in your Rapid applications.
Below we have a couple of input boxes linked to the 'Validate' button. Both input boxes have different validation messages attached to them, and we will go over some of the different validation types in the next page. For this validation type it will activate whenever you change the contents of the input boxes.
First name
Last name
Input boxes are not the only controls in Rapid that can be validated. Any control that has a validation header can have validation applied to it, and any control can be used to check validation, not just our 'Validate' button above. In our next example we will be validating the date control and the radio button controls.
Birthday
Gender
We've seen quite a few different controls with validation now, but there is more to cover! When in the Rapid Designer and control that has a validation header can be validated against. All controls can have a validation action applied to them, however the general use of this is to attach it to a button, like we have used throughout this page. Below are the remaining controls with validation.
Country
Not a robot
Today's weatherABCD

page.title: Validation details
